ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Overview of the controversial topics in aid- tied aid, aid efficiency, aid post-disaster and in failed states, changes in aid throughout history, the Peace Corps, NGOs, religiously-affiliated aid. Discussions are lively and thought-provoking and real world applications are very interesting. Definitely take it if you are considering working in aid, development, or NGOs or if you want a different perspective on US foreign policy.

The material is very interesting, and Prof. Simon is very friendly. Classes were sometimes a bit disorganized and lacked focus. Some of the articles that we read for class were barely relevant and not discussed in class. I would have preferred to focus more on the books, particularly Easterly.

A well-taught course that gives an extremely interesting overview of the issues and actors of development assistance. I would recommend this course to anyone who has even a passing interest in issues of poverty, global health, or development. It was definitely the highlight of my course schedule.
Yes, take it! It can get a little boring, but the readings are worth it!
